From: "Mike Woodhouse" <mikewoodhouse@...>
Subject: Introducing Me
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=199382914
X-Yahoo-Profile: mikewoodhouse

I've been "playing" with NNs and GAs for, golly (counts on fingers),
well over a decade now. I started with Backprop, experimented with
evolving weights rather than training, discovered SANE, branched
across to GP with GEP (Gene Expression Programming), moved back to
backprop and evolved weights. I've implemented (with varying degrees
of success) in C, VB (3/4/5/6), Delphi, Ruby and now I'm heading into
C# country. One of the reasons for the variety being that I often
build at least a feed-forward network as an early exercise in a
learning new language, not least because it always seems to be a fun
thing to build.

I've been frustrated by several deficiencies of the models I've built:
population stagnation/local minima problems, uncertainty as to network
topology, inability adequately to define an appropriate fitness
function amongst them. So having stumbled upon NEAT, I was thoroughly
impressed to discover the first two "issues" being handled - the third
is sadly much more specific to my own failings than those of my code ;-)

I joined the list a few weeks back and, in good newsgroup style have
been reading through the correspondence to date. I don't think I've
ever read through a newsgroup or mailing list that has such a high
signal-to-noise ratio: I've learned a tremendous amount just looking
over peoples' shoulders. Extracted from Yahoo!, tidied, formatted
(8pt, 2 columns) in Word, I still had over 300 pages to work through,
hence the delay between joining and introduction - I've not been idle!
There's probably a book in there somewhere if someone had the energy
to write it...

I've played around with various domains over time (XOR, OCR and some
simple games) but my most recent area of "research" has taken me back
to an old love betting on football matches (that's soccer to our
non-UK colleagues). My interest has largely been rekindled by the rise
and rise of the betting exchanges, where the margin to be overcome is
significantly lower than was the case through the traditional routes
of the bookmakers and, not inconsequentially, the opportunity to
actually keep making money is not curtailed by the bookies' tendency
to close winning accounts... I've been producing odds estimation
models for a few years based on my own variant of the ELO chess rating
system. I've used GAs to "tune" the rating system parameters but I've
always felt that the approach, and the (often extensive) structure
I've built upon it, was sub-optimal if not essentially flawed, but I
lacked the tools to take the domain back to a NN-based approach. Come
to think of it, I lacked the CPU power as well.

That said, the exercise hasn't been a complete disaster! I've had an
unquantifiably large amount of fun and while I can't claim to have
made an overall profit, my efforts to date have been better than
random (i.e. I haven't lost *too* much...)

Why sports betting, and match betting at that, rather than the
markets? Immediacy, I guess, which apart from the adrenaline rush
(:-)) offers far greater profit potential: a 1% "edge" per event (I
wish) is enormous when you consider that each season their are 1856
matches just in the English professional leagues. 1.01 ^ 1856 is about
104 million. Of course, that's unachievable in real life: firstly, the
odds aren't perfectly fair, if they were, random bets would break
even), secondly many of the events occur simultaneously and thirdly
the entire amount can't be staked on each event (the first loss would
rather tend to terminate the exercise). But capital can be reinvested
much more frequently and thus made to work far harder. And frankly,
I've had more success estimating the probabilities of sports match
outcomes than short-term stock price moves (my equity investing
"strategy" is mostly buy-and-hold...)

I'm currently engaged (in between tasks associated with settling in to
a new house) in amusing myself with the consideration of various ways
of approaching my problem domain and familiarising myself with
existing NEAT implementations, Ken's "canonical" C++ and Colin's C# in
particular. I expect to "roll my own" code because as a professional
developer that's where much of the fun lies, and it's not like I'm in
any hurry.

If you've reached this far, thanks for your forbearance.

Regards,

Mike Woodhouse
